body.head: Before you begin...
body.p: In this and subsequent exercises you will be using the XML editor Oxygen to work with data files we've prepared for you. Oxygen should be installed on your work stations already: you can start it up by just clicking on the Oxygen XML Editor icon on the desktop, or selecting it from the Programs menu in the usual way.

We recommend you to keep all the files you make during the exercises in a single folder. We refer to this below as your Work folder. We will put this in place in your home directory, with all the files you'll need.

div.head: Editing TEI-XML using Oxygen - 1
div.p:
In the first part of this little tutorial you will learn how to use Oxygen to :
create a born digital XML document
add XML tags to a document
continously validate the document against a simple schema
display the document in various ways

Oxygen can be configured for use in several languages, including English, French, German, and Italian. If you'd prefer to work in some language other than English, use the Preferences command, the first option on the Options menu (fifth from left on the menu bar), to change it. This tutorial mostly assumes you are using the English version, though some of the illustrations are taken from the French version, and so may not match exactly what you see on the screen.

div.head: The born-digital document
div.p: The TEI is not just for encoding ancient documents from their paper or stone originals. It's also useful for the creation of new documents, starting ex nihilo....

div.head: Creating a document

list.item: Start Oxygen.
Click on the New icon top left (or choose New from the File menu, or type CTRL-N) to open the New dialog box )

Oxygen offers you a choice of various pre-defined templates for your new document, grouped under four headings ("Recently used", "New Document", "Global templates", or "Framework templates" in English). These groups are organised hierarchically : you can open or close subgroups by clicking the blue key icon to the left of the folder icon.
Open the last group Framework templates, then within it TEI P5, then Bare, to choose a very simple TEI schema.
Click the Create button at the bottom. Oxygen displays a minimal TEI document, which we will now complete.

div.p: By default, Oxygen shows you a number of windows. In the centre is the main workspace, containing your document. At lower left, you can see the Summary window which gives you a view of the hierarchic structure of your document.
As you see, a TEI document is divided in two : the upper part, tagged teiHeader contains metadata ; the lower part, tagged text contains the data.

As before, you can open or close parts of the Outline display by clicking the blue key icon. If you click on a tag name in the Outline view, the corresponding part of the document itself is selected in the Editor window.

At the bottom of the Editor window you can see three buttons labelled Text Grid and Author. These change the way the document is displayed : for the moment, since we are not afraid of tags, we will stay in the default Text mode, but you may like to click on the others to see what they do.

Let's begin by giving our document the three pieces of essential metadata needed for every TEI document : a title, a note on its publication, and another note on its sources. Oxygen has proposed some default text for each which needs to be completed or corrected ...
Replace the word Title (between the tags title and /title) by a title for your document. It's up to you to find a good title! Something like Experimenting with Oxygen will do, but you may want to be more specific.
Replace the two other bits of text by some appropriate phrases. For example, you might put something like Unpublished draft or Distributed on my blog in the publication statement, depending on your ambitions for this text. For the sourceDesc, even though there is no pre-existing source, you are required to put something: we suggest An original work, produced as part of a TEI-Epidoc Workshop.

Oxygen always tries to keep your document valid. What happens if you mess things up?
Delete a few letters within any tag : for example, change publicationStmt to publicat.
Oxygen does its best. First, it changes the corresponding end-tag to match (so it becomes /publicat): the document is thus still well formed. But it's no longer valid -- there is no such element as publicat in the schema. Consequently the faulty tags are underligned in red, there's an error message at the foot of the screen, and on the right there are some red marks indicating visually where the error occurs. .
Click on one of the red marks and see if you can follow the logic by which one error leads to another.
Click CTRL-Z (or choose Undo from the Edit menu) to return to a state of grace ... you will see that the little red square at top right becomes green when all errors have been corrected.

Oxygen also encourages you to keep your document valid. It can offer you a choice of tags to enter, but it will offer only those which are valid at the current point in the document.
Put the cursor at the end of the 7th line, or the start of the 8th, between /title and /titleSmt;
type < and pause ;
the green square becomes red because you have not yet entered the name of an element.
Oxygen suggests a list of the tags which can legally appear at this place in the document : at this point, you can add an author element, or another title, close the titleStmt, or insert an XML comment.
Let's take the first suggestion : select author and hit RETURN. Oxygen will insert both start and end-tags for the new element.
Note that the cursor stays inside the opening tag author just in case you now want to enter some attributes for it (type a space if you are curious to see what attributes are available). Move the cursor one character to the right and type your name, since you are the author of the file.
You may like to experiment to see what other elements are available at other points in the document : as you will see, this is a really simple schema with very few elements.

div.head: Adding text to the document
div.p: Now let's start adding some real content to our document. It's up to you what you write and (within limits) how you tag it.

To start with, how will your document be organized? A document containing just one paragraph, though possible, seems unlikely. The schema we are using allows you to mark up :
sections or subsections or subsubsections or ... (we will call them all divisions). Tag these with div
headings for the divisions. Tag these with head
lists, also containing headings, labels and items. Tag these with list, head, label, or item as appropriate
paragraphs. Tag these with p Let's go !
In the rest of this part of the tutorial we will start showing you some of the tricks and short cuts provided by the Oxygen program. .

Firstly, a big question. Obviously, the program can't generate the actual content of the document we're writing, but do we really have to type in all the tags as well ? Not at all : Oxygen is there to help. You've already seen how it can suggest a list of possible elements to be inserted at a given point in the text. It can also propose tags to wrap around any part of the document.

list.item:
With your mouse, select the whole content of the body element, i.e. the start and end tags for the p and the three words it contains

Some text here

.
Type CTRL-E or choose XML Refactoring - Surround with Tags from the Document menu.
Oxygen offers you a choice of all the elements it knows about. Choose the one that makes sense here : div. Then click on Accept
This div element will contain the first section of your document. You might like to give it a title, by inserting a head element before its first paragraph.
It would also be useful to number your divisions explicitly : for that you can use the attribute n which is available on every TEI element, including div.
Put the cursor inside the div tag, just before the > et type a space. Oxygen offers a list of available attributes.
Choose n and hit RETURN. Oxygen warns you that you must supply a legal value for this attribute, and the cursor remains inside the quote marks.
Type (for example) 1, and your document becomes valid once more.

div.p: Your document should now look like this :

Now you need to add some text to the paragraph : hopefully a bit more interesting than some text here ! Describe your first reactions to Oxygen ; give us your views on the current economic crisis ; write about your childhood -- it's up to you! The point of the exercise is to get you used to the idea of writing in an XML editor as easily as you would write in a word processor.

No doubt you will soon feel the need for a new paragraph, or for a bulleted list. How do you close the current paragraph and start a new one? Just hitting RETURN a couple of times doesn't seem to work. Is there a better way of doing this without having to type the tags /p>

div.head: Divide and conquer
div.p: Let's assume you have several hundred words in one paragraph, which you now want to split up into several paragraphs.

list.item: Put the cursor at each point where you want to split the paragraph
Type CTRL-ALT-D or choose XML Refactoring - Split element from the Document menu.

div.p: You can of course do exactly the same thing to split up your one div element. Take care that you choose the right place to do the splitting though. You must put the cursor between two p elements, not within one of them.

div.head: Making tagged text readable
div.p: Are you beginning to worry about the amount of tagging in your document ?

You can tidy up the tagging you've inserted by clicking on the "Format and Indent" button, typing CTRL+SHIFT+P, or choosing Source->Format and Indent from the Document menu. But maybe you'd rather just get rid of all the tags ?

list.item: At the bottom of the screen there are three tabs : Text Grid and Author. Choose the last of these. The way your document is displayed now looks quite different, and there is also a new menu TEI P5. Choose Tags Display Mode and look at the various possibilities it offers
You can display the tags as little icons, large icons, or not at all
Note also that your document is now formatted -- different elements have different colours, and the layout is more like that of a word processor.
In Author mode, you can split an element just by hitting RETURN twice. Try it!

div.p: Later on, we will see how you can control the formatting of your document using a stylesheet.
After all this work, don't forget to save your document in your Work folder !

div.head: À la découverte d' Oxygen - 2
div.p:
In this second part of the exercise we'll experiment with using Oxygen to :
encode a pre-existing document in TEI XML
represent some typical literary structures

div.head: Sample text
div.p: In this essay we will encode a Petrarchan sonnet, respecting its organization into stanzas and lines. To make your life easier, we have prepared a transcription already for you, so you don't need to do quite so much typing as in the previous exercise...

div.head: Create a new document
div.p:
As you did before, open Oxygen and click on the New icon at top left to open the New document dialogue. This time, when asked to choose which schema to use, we suggest you select TEI P5 and then TEI-Lite. This will give you a more useful schema than the minimalist one we used in the first exercise.
As before, Oxygen gives you the basic TEI structure, with a few extra components.
Complete the TEI header quickly, as you did before. We suggest the following as title A Petrarchan Sonnet in TEI-XML format, and as source Transcription taken from "Il Canzoniere" di Francesco Petrarca, edited by Gianfranco Contini. Edizione Einaudi, 1964
Remove everything proposed as content for the body element, taking care to retain the body et /body tags.

div.head: Adding text to the document
div.p:
You can, of course, type out the poem for yourself as you did before. But this time we propose the following method :
Check that your cursor is between the body and /body tags in your empty document
Choose File -> Insert File from the Document menu (Note: Not the File Menu on the menu bar, but the one found under the Document Menu!)
Navigate to the file sonnet.txt which you will find in your working folder, select it and click Open.
Your document is full of red lines but don't panic! we will sort that out in a moment. Look at the error message at the foot of the screen and see if you understand it.

div.head: Adding structure to the body of a document
div.p:
The structure of a document is important. In this case, the body contains :
a heading ... to be tagged with head
an octet and a sestet ... both to be tagged with div
four stanzas ... to be tagged with lg
14 lines ... to be tagged with l
Let's go !

list.item: Select the first two lines Canzoniere (Rerum vulgarium fragmenta) VII
Type CTRL-E and choose head from the list of available tags ; then click Accept

For extra marks, you may want to cut this heading in two, distinguishing the number (which is the number of the sonnet) from the general title which precedes it. If so, put the cursor before the number VII and use CTRL-ALT-D or some other way of splitting the heading as you did in the previous exercise.

div.p: Now for the poem itself. Our goal is to have each verse line tagged l (line), each stanza tagged lg, the octet tagged div type="octet" and the sestet tagged div type="sestet".

Of course there's more than one way to do this. We suggest one fairly quick way, but feel free to experiment with other approaches !
Select with your mouse the whole of the text of the poem.
Surround the whole poem with one l.
All the red lines disappear and the little green square reappears ! Have we finished? Sorry, no : a document can be valid while still containing lies... and it's a lie that a sonnet contains only one line! Lies can also be dangerous : hit the Indentation button on the toolbar (or type CTRL-SHIFT-P).

Since the line endings are not explicit in the markup, Oxygen is not obliged to respect them when formatting the display. To be both honest and explicit, we need to split this one line into fourteen. (If you can't remember where to split the line, you can bring back the original display by typing CTRL-Z)

list.item: Put the cursor at the end of the first verse line and type ALT-SHIFT-D
Use the down arrow key to move down to the end of the next line and repeat
(Or, if you prefer to live dangerously, you can also cut and paste the sequence </l><l> at the end of each line).
When you've finished, check that everything is correct by typing CTRL-SHIFT-P or hitting the Indentation button again.

You now need to repeat essentially the same manoeuver for the stanzas : select all the lines and wrap them in an lg, then split that lg after the fourth, eighth, and 12th lines. (Take care that you do this splitting in the right place! your cursor should be between the end of one l and the start of the next, i.e. after the /l and before the following l)
Finally, we suggest wrapping the first two stanzas in a div type="octet" and the second two in a div type="sestet"

div.head: Changing the display
div.p: As you've already seen, Oxygen can display the hierarchic structure of our sonnet -- if you look in the Summary window to the left you should now see something like this :
And you can also, as before, switch to Author mode to see the text nicely formatted with no tags.

The way texts are displayed in Author mode is determined by a series of instructions supplied by a separate document called a stylesheet. We will learn more about this tomorrow. To conclude this part of the exercise we'll show you how to make a few changes in the Author mode display of your sonnet.

list.item: First, put your document into Text mode
Select XML Document et Associate stylesheet from the Document menu.
In the dialogue that opens, click the CSS tab. Click the arrow at extreme right, select "Look for local file" and then navigate to a file called petrarch.css in your Work folder. Press Select.
A line containing a "processing instruction" is added to the start of your document
Now see what happens when you switch to Author mode.

div.p:
You can edit the stylesheet to get different effects if you like. Open petrarch.css with Oxygen. But take care :
CSS is not itself an XML language, but its syntax is fairly self evident.
It is fairly simple to change the size of a font or the margins for all elements of a specified type
For this exercise, we suggest you just try changing the colour of the title from purple to red.
More complex transformations are easy with a more powerful stylesheet language called XSLT, as you will see tomorrow..

div.head: À la découverte d' Oxygen - 3
div.p:
In the third part of this tutorial you will learn how Oxygen can be used to :
transform an existing Word document into TEI XML
search for markup in a TEI XML document
transform a TEI XML document into a different format

div.head: Quelques documents historiques
div.p: Vous trouverez dans votre dossier Travaux un fichier nommé petain-sample.docx. Il contient trois communications du Maréchal Pétain, transcrits et annotes par un chercheur de l'universite de Nice, ensuite édité dans un Lexicometrica de 2005.
En voici le début dans le fichier Word:

Ce fichier contient :
trois transcriptions distinctes, chacune datée
des notices, qui figurent comme notes de bas de pages
des paragraphes
des titres

div.head: Transformation d'un fichier Word
div.p: Quoi faire pour transformer ce joli fichier en XML et travailler la-dessus avec Oxygen?

Nous pourrions l'exporter au format « plein text ». Nous pourrions aussi faire un copier-coller. Mais dans chaque cas, nous risquons la perte du formatage qui distingue (par exemple) les annotations en bas de page du texte annote. s.
Si le fichier Word est bien stylé, on peut le transformer en XML, sans perte d’information. L'outil OxGarage nous aidera.

list.item: Ouvrez votre Internet browser, et allez sur le site http://www.tei-c.org/ege-webclient/
Cliquez sur Text Documents. Dans la liste des formats de saisi proposée, cochez la case pour Microsoft Word Document.
Une liste des formats cibles proposés apparaît. Cochez la case pour TEI P5 XML.
En haut de l'écran un bouton Browse apparaît. Cliquez sur ceci, et naviguez jusqu'au fichier petain-sample.docx dans votre dossier Travaux.
Cliquez sur le grand bouton Convert et patientez.
Le site vous renvoie (après un bref délai) un fichier petain-sample.xml. Enregistrez-le dans votre dossier Travaux.

div.head: Structure du fichier
div.p: Voyons ce que le Garage aura fait de notre fichier Word. En tout cas, il est devenu un document TEI valide, même s'il pourrait etre amélioré.

list.item: Relancez Oxygen (si necessaire), et ouvrez le fichier que vous venez de recevoir du garage.
Oxygen vous avertit que ce fichier ne contient pas de retours à la ligne : ce n'est pas grave. Cliquez sur "format".

item.p: D'abord, explorez un peu la structure du fichier. La structuration est plus evidente dans la fenêtre Sommaire à gauche de l'ecran. Cliquez à gauche de chaque noeud pour l'ouvrir, ou pour l'enfermer. Par exemple, apres avoir cliqué à gauche de "text" et de "body", vous allez voir ceci:
Ensuite, si vous cliquez à gauche du deuxieme "div", vous allez voir ceci:

Vous allez vite comprendre que dans ce fichier, il y a quatre div, dont le premier ne contient que le titre du fichier. Apres cela, il y a trois div, contenant un head et une serie de p. Quelques-uns de ces p ne contient que de texte, mais il y en a aussi qui contiennent un hi, contenant un note, contenant des p emboites comme ceci :

list.item: Pourquoi? Notre fichier, comme tout autre fichier issu d'un outil bureautique, retient les annotations dans le texte à la point de référence. L'opération de stylage classique sera d'extraire les annotations, les numerotées, et les affichées en bas de page : une espece de transformation.

div.head: Correction du fichier
div.p: Une version corrigée est à votre disposition, si vous en avez besoin, dans le fichier petain-sample-corr.xml!

div.head: Transformation du fichier
div.p: Vous avez deja vu Oxygen faire une transformation de XML : si vous affichez votre document en mode Auteur, vous allez voir que les titres sont maintenant plus jolis, numerotés et mises en evidence, et que les annotations sont affichees avec une police plus petite, mais peut etre pas à l'endroit que vous les attendiez.

Essayons d'autre transformations. Il serait impressionant de transformer notre fichier directement en HTML ou PDF pour l'afficher, n'est-ce pas?
Sur le barre aux outils, il y a un bouton qui contient une fleche rouge. Cliquez la dessus (ou taper CTRL-MAJ-T, ou sélectionnez Document -> Transformation -> Appliquer le scenario de transformation )
En Oxygen un scenario de transformation associe un document avec une feuille de style, et la fait tourner. Par défaut, vous voyez TEI P5 XHTML et TEI P5 PDF. Séléctionnez le scenario qui vous plait, et regardez ce qu'il donne, en cliquant le bouton Transformer maintenant. Experimentez-l' autre !
Bien sur, on peut configurer ces transformations à volonté, et en créer des nouveaux. Pour vous en donner le goût, on va finir en vous proposant une transformation qui n'a rien à faire avec la visualisation.

La feuille de style qui controle une transformation s'écrit dans un autre langage XML, qui s'appelle XSLT : sujet fascinant, mais peut etre pas pour les debutants. Vous trouverez quelques exemplaires de feuilles de styles XSLT dans votre dossier. Pour en servir, il faut créer une nouvelle transformation en Oxygen
Cliquez sur la flèche rouge (CTRL-MAJ-T) de nouveau
Cliquez le bouton Nouveau pour ouvrir la fenetre Nouveau Scenario. Dans cette fenetre:
choisir un nom pour le scenario : on vous propose "texte-brut"
specifier la location du fichier XSL souhaité, en cliquant sur le petit icone dossier jaune à droite du champs XSL URL. Ceci vous permets de naviguer au dossier Travaux : sélectionner le fichier texte-brut.xsl et cliquer Ouvrir.
sélectionnez Saxon HE 9 du menu Transformateur
Cliquer Accepter pour terminer, et Transformer Maintenant pour voir le resultat.
Comme vous voyez, c'est possible de transformer notre document XML ou bien dans un format d'affichage, ou bien dans un format d'analyse tres classique.
